I was so proud to cast my vote today to pass #HR3, the Lower Prescription Drug Costs Now Act. This issue has been a top priority of mine since day one in office. Today, we took another step to deliver on our promise to #LowerDrugCosts #ForThePeople! pic.twitter.com/0wH8npIztY
When the workers in my district show such resolve, how can I show any less? We must pass the #PROAct and I will do whatever I can to make that happen. #PROActChat #1u

A5: I’m reminded of the GM workers in my district who recently went on strike. They faced weeks without pay, their health insurance was taken away, and yet not one person crossed the picket line. In the end, their solidarity won out and they were able to win real gains.

A5: This effort is only a drop in the bucket - employers spend an estimated $340 million per year on union-busting consultants. That’s why this fight is so important. In the face of such opposition we cannot waver in our support for the workers on the front lines. #PROActChat

A5: Quite simply, they’re afraid. They’re afraid of workers having a real voice in the workplace. They’re afraid of the power solidarity wields to raise the standard of living for all. And they’re afraid of creating a more equitable system where labor is rewarded for their work.

A4: The #PROAct also removes a longstanding impediment to free speech – the ban on secondary boycotts. Removing this ban allows workers everywhere to come together in solidarity and show their support by refusing to cross a picket line. #PROActChat

A4: Most importantly, the #PROAct prohibits employers from permanently replacing striking workers. It guarantees that all strikes are protected, regardless of their duration or scope. With the #PROAct workers will be able to exercise their rights without fear of losing their job.

A3: But I have also been spreading the word far and wide via press interviews, town halls, social media, and any other opportunity I get. That’s why I think having a #PROActChat like this one is so helpful!

A3: Fortunately, I think the #PROAct has a lot momentum already. When I’m talking with constituents in #MI09, I witness firsthand the excitement around empowering workers through the #PROAct. #PROActChat

A2: By making it easier to organize without fear of retaliation, setting a clear path to a first contract, and protecting the right to strike, the #PROAct empowers workers to use their voice. Only by using their voice effectively can workers win these types of working conditions.

A2: From better wages and health care to providing due process in the workplace and a healthier work-life balance, unions are proven to build better workplaces. With only 6.4% of private sector workers unionized, workers lack adequate bargaining power to bring about real change.

A2: Data suggests that almost half of non-union workers would choose to join a union if given the opportunity. The #PROAct would help close the gap between desire and action by removing the barriers to unionization created by decades of resistance to the labor movement.

A1: Because the #PROAct is vital to rebuilding our middle-class! We’ve seen productivity ⬆️ yet real wages are stagnant. We’ve seen income inequality ⬆️, union membership ⬇️, and the right to organize eroded to almost nothing. Without a change these trends will only worsen.
Join us starting at 1pm ET! #PROActChat https://twitter.com/CWAUnion/status/1204458468935159808 …

Without safeguards like these in place, I cannot in good conscience vote to authorize more funding for this President’s dangerous military agenda. 
 
As such, I voted against the #NDAA conference report.

If we fail to do this, we cannot hope to adequately fund priorities at home—our crumbling infrastructure, the safety of our water, and more—that, make no mistake, are essential to maintaining our national security.

I believe we can do that and still protect our troops from reckless wars and ensure our water is safe to drink. 

I also believe we can protect American jobs and security while getting our country’s bloated military budget in order.

So many Michiganders in the 9th district work hard every day to manufacture defense materials that keep our troops safe. I value their work and will continue engaging with them to protect good-paying Michigan jobs.

Critically important provisions have been stripped from the text, like my bill to make clear that this President lacks the authority to launch a dangerous war with Iran and language to control the discharge of #PFAS into our drinking water.
While I believe the House bill we passed this summer met this standard, I fear the bill before us now does not.
I appreciate that compromise is the essence of this body. But there are some principles on which I cannot compromise. Chief among those are the health and wellbeing of Michiganders.

This summer, I voted to pass the House’s National Defense Authorization Act (#NDAA)—a bill that would prevent an unconstitutional war in Iran, enshrine comprehensive protections from dangerous #PFAS chemicals, block funding for a wasteful border wall, and more.

Still, I remain hopeful. All of us humans share the same yearnings, & we must fight to realize them everywhere. 

Today, I honor the #DalaiLama, the Tibetan people, and all other ethnic and religious minorities — and indeed Han Chinese — struggling for free expression in China.
The government has developed and deployed in Tibet many of the surveillance techniques and technologies in Tibet that they are now using to our horror in Xinjiang and exporting to other countries.

And what have we seen since? The Chinese have moved many thousands of Han people into Tibet, limited the learning of Tibetan language and the study of religion, and otherwise instituted a slow cultural genocide.

On my way home, I stopped in Los Angeles to interview the Dalai Lama about the struggle for rights and autonomy for the Tibetan people. A few weeks later, he was announced as the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize. 30 years ago today, he was awarded that prize on Human Rights Day.

I got to Chengdu when the Tiananmen Massacre occurred, and I was a witness to the violence and repression that followed. Since I couldn’t get into what China calls Tibet, I traveled in Tibetan regions of Sichuan and Gansu provinces (what Tibetans call Kham).

Thirty summers ago, I was a graduate student deeply immersed in #Tibetan religion, philosophy, language and culture. I traveled to China to try to get into #Tibet, even though the Chinese government had closed the Tibet Autonomous Region to outsiders during a wave  of repression.
